items.title: Reply to a forwarded message
How to get data from SQLite3 table?
items.body:
Perhaps the question is not quite on the topic, but my brain explodes! I can not solve the problem. When a person first starts a dialogue with a bot, he must choose a language. This data is entered into the database. If suddenly a person starts the dialogue again, the bot will not ask him for a language, but will make a request to the database.
```python
@bot.message_handler(commands = ["start"])
def start(message):
    user_id = message.from_user.id
    search_language(user_id = user_id)
    if search_language == "EN":
        bot.send_message(message.from_user.id, "Hello!")
    elif search_language == "RU":
        bot.send_message(message.from_user.id, "Привет!")
```
I have two files. One is the bot itself, and the second is the database.
```python
@ensure_connection
def check_db(conn, force: bool = False):
    c = conn.cursor()
    if force:
        c.execute("DROP TABLE IF EXISTS user_language")
    c.execute("""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS user_language (
            id           INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
            user_id      INTEGER NOT NULL,
            language     TEXT NOT NULL
        )
    """)
    conn.commit()

@ensure_connection
def search_language(conn, user_id: int):
    c = conn.cursor()
    user_id = user_id()
    c.execute("SELECT language FROM user_language WHERE user_id = (?)", (user_id))
    conn.commit()
```
Whatever I do, I encounter a lot of mistakes. I tried a bunch of methods, but nothing helps.

Hi
I wanted to know how to add the telegram bot to asyncio event loop.

items.title: ('Connection aborted.', OSError("(104, 'ECONNRESET')"))
items.body:
1. What version of pyTelegramBotAPI are you using?
Latest

2. What OS are you using?
Xubuntu 20.04

3. What version of python are you using?
3.8

It seems to me that this problem is pretty common, bur since I could not find any solution, I would like to submit it again.
The bot I am building is currently hosted on a linux virtual machine on my computer, and uses polling to get updates.

The bot reads all messages in a group, so that it can keep track of most and least active members.
But I also implemented functions to handle user input, such as commands or buttons. The problem is, if no user gives any input for a sufficient amount of time (eg. 10-15 minutes), the next time somebody does, the request to the relative Telegram API will raise
`('Connection aborted.', OSError("(104, 'ECONNRESET')"))`

so that the bot has to start a new connection, and the user has to wait for between 30 and 60 seconds to see the expected output.

Here is a simplified version of my code (it could be used to reproduce the problem)

```
import telebot
import logging
import schedule
import time
from threading import Thread

TOKEN = TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN
bot = telebot.TeleBot(TOKEN)

logger = telebot.logger
log_format='%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s'
logging.basicConfig(format=log_format,level=logging.DEBUG,datefmt='%-d %b %Y - %H:%M:%S')


group_id = GROUP_ID       #The group where my bot counts messages


message_counter = {}

@bot.message_handler(commands=['start','help'])                 #Handles commands /start and /help
def start_fun(message):
    user_id = message.from_user.id
    logging.info(str(user_id)+" requested /start or /help.")
    for i in range(10):                                         #Maximum of 10 retries
        try:
            logging.info("Attempt no. "+str(i+1))
            bot.send_message(message.chat.id,"Hello!")
        except Exception as e:
            logging.error(e)
        else:
            logging.info("Done")
            break

@bot.message_handler(func = lambda m : True)                     #Handles every message, inside the group
def general_handler(message):                                    #Passively counts the messages for each 
    if (message.chat.id != group_id):                            #user, only inside the group
        return
    user_id = str(message.from_user.id)
    logging.info("Message from "+user_id)
    if (user_id not in message_count):
        message_count[user_id] = 0
    else:
        message_count[user_id] += 1


def scheduled_task():                                             #example of scheduled task
    for i in range(10):
        try:
            logging.info("Trying to do scheduled task")
            bot.send_message(group_id,"I will say this every day!")
        except Exception as e:
            logging.error(e)
        else:
            logging.info("Done")


def schedule_checker():                                          #checks every seconds for pending tasks
    while True:
         schedule.run_pending()
         time.sleep(1)

schedule.every().day.at("13:00").do(scheduled_task)
Thread(target=schedule_checker).start()                           #Opens a new thread so it does not
                                                                                          #interfere with polling


while True:                                                       #Loop with infinite retries, so it
        try:                                                         #does not stop if there is an error
                bot.polling(none_stop=True)
        except Exception as e:
                logging.error(e)
                time.sleep(1)

```


This is an example from my debug log

```
15 Jun 2020 - 10:48:32 - DEBUG - Starting new HTTPS connection (1): api.telegram.org:443
15 Jun 2020 - 17:47:00 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=1&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 23
15 Jun 2020 - 17:47:20 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=1&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 23
15 Jun 2020 - 17:47:40 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=1&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 23
15 Jun 2020 - 17:48:00 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=1&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 23
15 Jun 2020 - 17:48:20 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=1&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 23
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:07 - INFO - Message from 123456789
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:16 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861246&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 284
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:16 - INFO - Message from 234567891
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:26 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861247&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 303
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:26 - INFO - Message from 234567891
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:42 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861248&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 562
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:42 - INFO - Message from 123456789
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:44 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861249&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 318
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:44 - INFO - Message from 123456789
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:51 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861250&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 292
15 Jun 2020 - 17:50:51 - INFO - Message from 234567891
15 Jun 2020 - 17:51:07 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861251&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 324
15 Jun 2020 - 17:51:07 - INFO - Message from 123456789
15 Jun 2020 - 17:51:10 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861252&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 553
15 Jun 2020 - 17:51:10 - INFO - Message from 123456789
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:21 - INFO - 11223344 requested /start or /help
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:21 - INFO - Attempt no. 1
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:40 - ERROR - ('Connection aborted.', OSError("(104, 'ECONNRESET')"))
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:41 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "GET /TOKEN/getUpdates?offset=456861489&timeout=20 HTTP/1.1" 200 23
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:41 - INFO - Attempt no. 2
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:41 - DEBUG - Starting new HTTPS connection (4): api.telegram.org:443
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:41 - DEBUG - https://api.telegram.org:443 "POST /TOKEN/sendMessage?chat_id=11223344&text=Hello!" 200 2878
15 Jun 2020 - 19:20:41 - INFO - Done
```

To sum up:

1) No problems as long as the get_updates() function is called to retrieve updates, such as for counting messages in the group

2) When a command is given to the bot, it might give the error and then take 20-30 seconds to start a new connection (the second attempt is always successful)

3) The same problem happens when trying to execute scheduled tasks (which, in my case, all require calling the Telegram API functions)

4) The connection reset error does not happen if the commands are given in a short amount of time, i.e. the error will happen again if no command is given in 10-15 minutes


Thanks to the try-except loops I managed to prevent the bot from crashing, but users still often face these long waiting times. 

Is there a solution?



Thanks

Here is a ve-e-ery reduced version of my poller.py (systemd restarts it in case of a failure):
```
@bot.message_handler(content_types=['text'])
def text_reply(message):
    # Message processing, updating database
    # Confirmation sometimes fails to be delivered to the user
    bot.reply_to(message, ds[command]['post_message'].format(amount))

print(bot.polling())
```

At the same time I have a cron job which runs another script (`cron.py` for sending reminders to the same users from the same bot) which works just fine. For now I'm thinking about restarting `poller.py` every N minutes :(.

Does anyone have an idea of what might be wrong or how to get more information about this problem?

items.title: ValueError: json_type should be a json dict or string.
items.body:
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of pyTelegramBotAPI are you using? 3.6.7

2. What OS are you using? Ubuntu 14.04

3. What version of python are you using? 3.4

My code
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

# This is a simple echo bot using decorators and webhook with BaseHTTPServer
# It echoes any incoming text messages and does not use the polling method.

from http.server import BaseHTTPRequestHandler, HTTPServer

import logging
import ssl
import config
import telebot

API_TOKEN = config.TOKEN

WEBHOOK_HOST = config.ip
WEBHOOK_PORT = 8443  # 443, 80, 88 or 8443 (port need to be 'open')
WEBHOOK_LISTEN = '0.0.0.0'  # In some VPS you may need to put here the IP addr

WEBHOOK_SSL_CERT = './webhook_cert.pem'  # Path to the ssl certificate
WEBHOOK_SSL_PRIV = './webhook_pkey.pem'  # Path to the ssl private key

# Quick'n'dirty SSL certificate generation:
#
# openssl genrsa -out webhook_pkey.pem 2048
# openssl req -new -x509 -days 3650 -key webhook_pkey.pem -out webhook_cert.pem
#
# When asked for "Common Name (e.g. server FQDN or YOUR name)" you should reply
# with the same value in you put in WEBHOOK_HOST

WEBHOOK_URL_BASE = "https://%s:%s" % (WEBHOOK_HOST, WEBHOOK_PORT)
WEBHOOK_URL_PATH = "/%s/" % (API_TOKEN)

logger = telebot.logger
telebot.logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)

bot = telebot.TeleBot(API_TOKEN)


# WebhookHandler, process webhook calls
class WebhookHandler(BaseHTTPRequestHandler):
    server_version = "WebhookHandler/1.0"

    def do_HEAD(self):
        self.send_response(200)
        self.end_headers()

    def do_GET(self):
        self.send_response(200)
        self.end_headers()

    def do_POST(self):
        if self.path == WEBHOOK_URL_PATH and \
           'content-type' in self.headers and \
           'content-length' in self.headers and \
           self.headers['content-type'] == 'application/json':
            json_string = self.rfile.read(int(self.headers['content-length']))

            self.send_response(200)
            self.end_headers()

            update = telebot.types.Update.de_json(json_string)
            bot.process_new_messages([update.message])
        else:
            self.send_error(403)
            self.end_headers()


# Handle '/start' and '/help'
@bot.message_handler(commands=['help', 'start'])
def send_welcome(message):
    bot.send_message(message.chat.id, 'Test 1 command')


# Handle all other messages
@bot.message_handler(func=lambda message: True, content_types=['text'])
def echo_message(message):
    bot.send_message(message.chat.id, 'Test 2 command')


# Remove webhook, it fails sometimes the set if there is a previous webhook
bot.remove_webhook()

# Set webhook
# Beacuse telegram bot api server will check webhook server is alive.
# Here we need set webhook after server started manually.
bot.set_webhook(url=WEBHOOK_URL_BASE + WEBHOOK_URL_PATH,
                certificate=open(WEBHOOK_SSL_CERT, 'r'))

# Start server
httpd = HTTPServer((WEBHOOK_LISTEN, WEBHOOK_PORT),
                   WebhookHandler)

httpd.socket = ssl.wrap_socket(httpd.socket,
                               certfile=WEBHOOK_SSL_CERT,
                               keyfile=WEBHOOK_SSL_PRIV,
                               server_side=True)

httpd.serve_forever()
```

items.title: updating telegram bot api
items.body:
hi,
Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks!

1. What version of pyTelegramBotAPI are you using?
latest from GitHub
2. What OS are you using?
no matter, but mine is windows 10 64 bit
3. What version of python are you using?
3.6 and 3.7
the telegram api like fields and functions are out of date and needs refactoring
things like polls, (including PollOption and PollAnswer, KeyboardButtonPoll), markdown v2 which has been added in jan 23th 2020, SetChatPermission, setChatStickerSet, deleteChatStickerSet, and other methods and fields which has been added
this makes it possible to make more responsive bots easily with pytelegrambotapi
